resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.Text: Welcome to the Powerful Questions and Active Listening module. Likely, you have heard these terms before. Perhaps, though, you are unfamiliar with what they mean in the context of Step UP. This presentation will clarify the meaning and use of these essential coaching tools. Thank you for taking the time to participate in this presentation and for being a Step UP coach.

A Step UP coaching session is like a conversation, and as you know from your own experience, the best conversations happen when there is genuine interest between the two participants. When you are in a good conversation, you are not thinking about what questions you will ask; you are not concerned with right or wrong responses. Instead, you listen closely, without judging, and ask questions to help clarify and discover new insights. Thats exactly what it means to ask powerful questions, your most important coaching tool.

Powerful questions help students think deeply and discover their own answers, solutions and ideas. They are open-ended and require an extended response. In other words, a question that can be answered in a couple of words is not a powerful question. Powerful questions help move the conversation forward. The good news for you is that students do most of the talking; your job is to ask good, non-judgmental questions and then listen closely to the responses.

Powerful questions help students think deeply and discover their own answers, solutions and ideas. They are open-ended and require an extended response. In other words, a question that can be answered in a couple of words is not a powerful question. Powerful questions help move the conversation forward. The good news for you is that students do most of the talking; your job is to ask good, non-judgmental questions and then listen closely to the responses.

Asking powerful questions takes some practice but there are some tips that might make it easier. Click on each student below to hear a tip on asking powerful questions.

Silence is good! Get comfortable with silence. When you ask me a thoughtful question, I need some time to think before I respond. Give me some time and wait for me to reply. I will, I promise!

You dont need to know all the answers. Sometimes all I need is someone to listen and give me a little feedback now and then. I came to you to be a coach, not my professor. I dont need another lecture. I need you to guide me into discovering my own answers. Its much more meaningful to me when I can solve my own problems.

After you ask powerful questions, your next important job is to listen carefully to the response.

This also may be a new skill that sounds easy and logical. However, sometimes instead of listening to students, coaches are thinking of what question to ask next.

Instead, trust that the next question will come to you in the moment. Give your students your undivided attention, and be careful not to judge, no matter what the student says. Powerful questions sometimes lead to surprising responses. Embrace whatever comes up.

There are several active listening techniques to use as you coach. One good strategy is to summarize what you have heard the student say. In that way, the student knows youve been listening carefully and have a good understanding of the situation. Another way to achieve that is to ask the student some clarifying questions to help you get a clear picture and help the student think more deeply. You might also invite the student to elaborate on their response. One other technique is to use body language that says you are 100% engaged in the conversation. You can do that by maintaining eye contact, by sitting up and leaning towards the student. That shows you are paying close attention.

Hopefully this presentation has given you a taste for powerful questions and active listening. Lots more information is available, and this is not the only introduction you will receive. You will get more help and practice in the Step UP workshops. A list of powerful questions is in your manual, and there is more information available on the Step UP Canvas site as well as many You Tube videos online. In addition, you can borrow books, articles and videos about coaching from the Step UP office.
